data.test_name: Some Basic Concepts of Chemistry and Stoichiometry (Easy)

1.q_string: Consider an assumption that air contains \(22.4 \%\) oxygen. How many moles of oxygen atoms are there in \(1\) litre of the air under standard conditions?

Elements \(X\) and \(Y\) combine to form two compounds \(X Y\) and \(X_{2} Y\). Find the atomic weight of \(X\) and \(Y\), if the weight of \(0.1\) moles of \(X Y\) is \(10 \mathrm{~g}\) and \(0.05\) moles of \(X_{2} Y\) is \(9 \mathrm{~g}\):

q_option: \(67.2\) litres of \(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})\) at STP is produced for every mole of Al that reacts.
\(11.2\) litres \(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})\) at STP is produced for every mole \(\mathrm{HCl}\) (aq) consumed.
\(6\) litres \(\mathrm{HCl}(\mathrm{aq})\) is consumed for every \(3\) litres \(\mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})\) produced.
\(33.6\) litres \(\mathrm{H}_{2}\) (g) is produced regardless of the temperature and pressure for every mole of \(\mathrm{Al}\) that reacts.
1.q_string:
Which of the following is true for the given reaction?

\(2 \mathrm{Al}(\mathrm{s})+6 \mathrm{HCl}(\mathrm{aq}) \rightarrow 2 \mathrm{Al}^{3+}(\mathrm{aq})+6 \mathrm{Cl}^{-}(\mathrm{aq})+3 \mathrm{H}_{2}(\mathrm{~g})\)

Under the same conditions of temperature and pressure, \(2\) litres of \(\mathrm{SO}_{2}, 3\) litres of chlorine, \(6\) litres of hydrogen, \(5\) litres of nitrogen and \(4\) litres of \(\mathrm{CO}_{2}\) are collected.

Which of the following is the correct arrangement of these gases in increasing order of the number of molecules of the collected gases?

How much sugar \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{12} \mathrm{H}_{22} \mathrm{O}_{11}\right)\) will be required if each person on the earth is given \(100\) molecules of sugar? The population of the earth is \(3 \times 10^{10}\).
Which one will have the maximum number of water molecules?
The number of molecules of a gas at STP present in \(1 \mathrm{cc}\) is known as:
The number of atoms present in \(0.1\) moles of a triatomic gas is:
When a metal is burnt, its weight is increased by 24 percent. The equivalent weight of the metal will be:
What is the amount of water produced when \(8 \mathrm{~g}\) of hydrogen is reacted with \(32 \mathrm{~g}\) of oxygen?
How many millilitres of \(0.5~\mathrm{M}\) \(\mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{SO}_{4}\) are needed to dissolve \(0.5 \mathrm{~g}\) of copper(II) carbonate?
Calculate the mass of sodium hydroxide required to make \(500 \mathrm{ml}\) of \(0.10 \mathrm{M}\) solution.
The atomic weight of metal (M) is \(27\) and its equivalent weight is \(9\). The formula of its chloride will be:
The equivalent weight of bivalent metal is \(32.7 \mathrm{~g} / \mathrm{eq}\). The molecular weight of its chloride is:
How many carbon atoms are present in \(0.5\) moles of oxalic acid \(\left(\mathrm{C}_{2} \mathrm{H}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{4}\right)\)?
